Michigan Ongoing Health & Safety Training Refresher 2023
Section 3: Prevention & Control of Infectious Disease (Including Immunizations)

Structuring and Managing the Environment

Structuring and Managing the Environment of our child care sites is another important way to keep everyone healthy. There are several practical steps we can take.

The first thing we can do to structure and manage our environment has to do with how we use our space. Select each flashcard to read more about the many practical ways to use our space that can keep everyone healthy.

Provide enough space to avoid crowding

The first thing is to provide enough space to avoid crowding. The more square footage of space provided per child, the better. More space reduces the concentration of germs.

Minimize sharing of space and surfaces among groups

Minimize sharing of space and surfaces among groups. Avoid the intermixing of groups of children. Donâ€™t use a room for several different groups of children. In other words, let each group have its own assigned area.

Avoid use of bare floor or carpet to change diapers

Centers must avoid the use of the floor to change diapers. Using the floor to change diapers, disposable training pants or soiled underwear contaminates the floor and could allow crawling or walking in this area to spread germs, therefore this should be avoided. Licensed homes are allowed to use the floor if they do not have a changing table but it must be an area of the floor just used for diaper changing and it must be a non-absorbent easily sanitized surface with a changing pad between the child and the surface.

Choose surfaces that can be easily cleaned

Finally, Choose surfaces that can be easily cleaned. The best surfaces to use are nonporous smooth surfaces. Soft materials, such as blankets and towels and throw rugs, should be easy to put in a washing machine and washed often.

Provide

Providing enough toilets and sinks will allow each group to have their own.

Separate

Separate food preparation area from other areas, especially the toileting and diapering areas. Centers are required to have a sink used exclusively for handwashing. Best practice for all providers is that the sink used for food prep should not be used for handwashing after diapering.

Make

Make sure to have systems checked by an American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE)-certified heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning contractor.

Practice

Practice Integrated Pest Management is a system of pest control that uses the least toxic methods to avoid and control pests. Techniques include using screens on doors and windows, filling holes, and eliminating standing water and open trash.
